questions.question_text:
Given the code fragment:
List<String> empDetails = Arrays.asList("100, Robin, HR",
"200, Mary, AdminServices",
"101, Peter, HR");
empDetails.stream()
.filter(s-> s.contains("1"))
.sorted()
.forEach(System.out::println); //line n1
What is the result?

choices.A: 100, Robin, HR 101, Peter, HR line n1.
choices.C: 100, Robin, HR 101, Peter, HR 200, Mary, AdminServices

discussion.content: Answer is A

Selected Answer: A
A is correct, prints "100, Robin, HR 101, Peter, HR". Tested.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.

A is correct
100, Robin, HR
101, Peter, HR

Selected Answer: C
C is correct since Exception classes in multi-catch must be unrelated. Also if superclass and sublass are caught then code must first catch subclass and then superclass.
Option C is correct despite the fact that the code wouldnt still compile because of error on line 5 (missing closing bracket in the if)

Option A can't compile 
Types in multi-catch must be disjoint: 'java.lang.NumberFormatException' is a subclass of 'java.lang.Exception'

comments.content: it is not just because of readability. multi-catch can't have parent and child together. Exception is parent of both ArithmeticException and NumberFormatException.

discussion.content:
Answer C is better than A.
Code is more readable.

Ans: C. If you do 
A, you still get this exception The exception ArithmeticException is already caught by the alternative Exception
Answer is C
Answer is C
A is correct
C is correct

choices.C: Replace line 26 with: } catch (ArithmeticException | NumberFormatException e) {
choices.B: Replace line 26 with: } catch (Exception | ArithmeticException | NumberFormatException e) {
